div.p: THE READY VVAY TO TRVE REPENTANCE:

OR A Godly, and Learned Treatise, of the Repentance of Mary Magdalen: opened in diuers Sermons at the first; begun in little Alhallowes vpon the Wall, London, the 21. day of Septemb. 1616. and continued in S. Peters Church in Sandwich; contayning Doctrine of FAITH.
By HARIM WHITE Bachelor of Diuinity, and Chaplyn to his most Excellent Maiesty.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT Vertuous, Graue, Wise, and Religious Gentlewoman, Mris. Dorothey Dalby, Widow, his deare and naturall Mother: HARIM WHITE, her dutifull and onely Sonne, wisheth, in this life prosperity; and in that which is to come, eternall felicity.
div.p:
THings deferred, and long in expectation, afford the more ioy in the fruition. You haue (I acknowledge
most deare and louing Mother) hitherto reaped nothing at all, for all that you haue so largely and long since sowne: but haue with the wise Husbandman, still patiently waited for the fruitfull time of Haruest.

Now therefore, in some measure to comfort you, (though at the last) as our Sauiour willeth his Disciples, so doe I you, To lift vp your eyes, for now the Regions are already Albae white, euen to the Haruest. Ioh. 4. 35. And although they bee not all Siccae, dry, and throughly ripe at once▪ yet let our small beginning bee acceptable, and encourage you with hope of the rest in due time. All Graines are not ripe together, but euery kinde hath it owne proper, and
fit season. Heere first we beginne with Faith, and purpose (God blessing vs) to goe on with Hope, and end with Loue, which threefold Cable shall neuer bee broken. I could finde none in right (amongst the many more fit then your selfe, to whose care and protection I might commit this shiftlesse and helplesse Orphan: it beeing originally, and properly your own Issue. If therefore you shall bee pleased with these my first fruites, and fauourably interpret these my first endeauours: you shall thereby encourage mee to tender to your view, workes of greater importance heereafter. And in the interim (as duty bindeth mee) I will not cease to solicite God by
prayer for your continuall prosperity; and that when hee shall please to take you from this earthly mansion, you may ascend into the euerlasting habitation of glorie. And thus in all filiall obsequy I humbly take my leaue this third of Ian. 1617.

closer.signed: Your euer obedient, louing Sonne. HARIM WHITE.

div.head: To the Religious, and well affected Reader.
div.p:
SEeing the World, at this day, so generally transported, with such dangerous, and strange Doctrines; and that all men (almost) hunting after nouelties, doe so eagerly desire that which is pestilent and noysome; in the meane while loathing and reiecting, that which is wholsome and good. It therefore beseemeth all men, (that render the glory of God) but specially
the Ministers of his word, diligently to shew to the people, the true difference betweene verum, and apparens bonum, that is, between • that which is good indeed, and that which seemeth to be so▪ especially in all great and fundamentall poynts of Saluation. To which purpose, I haue diuulged this little Treatise, which in it owne particular, shall (I doubt not) but performe this Office, to which end it is sent: and be as a defensatiue in health against the day of sicknesse, and as a preseruatiue in life, against the day of death. Wherin I soare not with the towring Eagle, into the clouds, neither deale I with Questions of difficulty, (which respect the learned and great wits; let such as list climbe into the third Heauen, and shew from thence high misteries, and vnheard of Reuelations) but casting my selfe vpon the ground, with all humility, I study to informe the meanest of
Gods children (after a plaine and easie manner) in those things, which necessarily appertaine to their eternall happinesse. And amongst the many behoofefull points of Christian Religion, I find none at this day, more necessary to bee taught and embraced, then this of Faith and true Repentance; seeing that fancy is generally reputed Faith, and conceit Conscience, and that Hypocrisie walketh in equall compare with Piety. I had no purpose at the first preaching heereof, to haue committed the same to Print, neither did I euer value it worth the Presse or publike view: only contenting my selfe with the discharge of my duty, and edification of my priuate flocke. But being ouer-ruled heerein, by the importunate intreaty of some of my hearers, and louing friends, I could not denie their request, seeing it intended the publike good. Vse it therefore Godly Reader, and meditate therein for
thy comfort: If thou reapest any profit thereby, giue God the praise, and thou hast sufficiently rewarded my paines. Farewell.

closer.dateline: From my Parsonage house, of S. Peters in Sandwich in Kent, this 3. of Ian. 1617.
closer.signed: Thy vnfaigned Louer in Christ Iesus. HARIM WHITE.

div.head: THE READY WAY to true Repentance. OR A learned, profitable, and comfortable Discourse of the Faith, and Repentance of MARY MAGDALEN, fit for the time, and profitable for all that loue the Lord in sincerity.

epigraph.q: Many Sinnes are forgiuen her, for she loued much.

div.p:
THis Parcell of Scripture, is the conclusion of the notable Story of Mary Magdalen, and her Repentance, with the circumstances, and occurrences thervnto belonging. A Doctrine and practise indeed, of vs too much neglected: but as we
see heere, by the Holy Ghost, & holy Church carefully registred, and by Mary Magdalen to the full performed. The sequell whereof is no lesse then Remissio peccatorum, the remssion of Sinnes.

div.head: Many sinnes are forgiuen her, for she loued much.
div.p: THe most memorable and admirable example of true Repentance is now deliuered.

She was the very filth of sinne, Sentina malorum, one that set her selfe to sale, Prostibulum inter gentes; an insatiable Woman, Qu • prostituit se omnibus, hauing her Chastity at command for money, the by-word of the people, one pointed at, the very scumme and scoffe of the world, it should seeme a sinne • aboue measure, and such a one was Mary Magdalen.

lg.l: But behold the lost Groat is found,
The Strayed sheepe is sought vp,
And Mary Magdalen hath truely repented.

div.p: The Kingdome of Heauen it seemes now suffers violence. Math. 11. 12. and whores and theeues enter in before you. Mat. 21. 31. Facilius est enim (as one well saith) deploratissimos peccatores, ad meliora reuocare, &c. It is an easier thing to bring to Repentance the vildest sinner, then such a one as swelleth in conceit of his owne Righteousnes.
They that be whole need not the Phisition, but they that be sicke: Hee came not to call the righteous but sinners to repentance. Luke 5. 32.
And this Conuersion of a sinner is indeed a supernaturall worke.
Before we enter into the discourse of the definition of Repentance, I think it not amisse to vse some description thereof, which for default (as Logicians affirme) may stand in stead of a definition.

div.head: Poenitentia, Repentance to a sinner.
div.p:
It is the Monosherosh, or Vnicornes horne, soueraigne against poyson. It is the true Methridate, good in the mournefull time of Pestilence.
It is Iacobs Ladder, Scala Coeli, the Ladder of Heauen, by which all must needs ascend, that will goe thither. It is Regia via, the Kings high way, the onely beaten and trodden path, that leadeth to eternall blisse. It is the translating of Henoch, that is, of sinfull man, from naturall affections, to spirituall inclinations It is the Chariot of Elias, whereby we are carried directly vnto God. It is the Red Sea, that drownes Pharaoh and all his hoast, the spirituall Pharaoh, the Diuell, Sinne, Death and Condemnation. It is the Salt the Prophet vsed, to make sweet the bitter waters of Iericho. It is the leauen that doth season, and make sauory the whole lumpe vnto God. It is the wombe of the Church, wherein Sonnes and Daughters are begotten to God. It is the birth of Nicodemus, whereby we are truly regenerate. It is the true Balsum, the most precious oyle that man can vse for any wound of the soule. It is the right Apopanax, or Panacea, soueraigne for euery disease of the So • le, except wilfull sinne against the Holy Ghost. It is the leaues of the Tree of life, that serue to heare the people withall Reu. 22.

div.head: Now Poenitere, to Repent, is

list.item: The charge and commandement of God.

The counsell and exhortation of the
Patriarkes,
Prophets, and
Apostles.
The practise of the Church in all ages.
The ioy of Heauen, and paine of Hell.

div.p: For God and his Angells reioyce at it, the Diuell and his instruments doe grieue at it.
I cannot compare Repentance to any thing better then to the Spring.

True Repentance beares the true figure of a liuely spring: for as the Winter is the benumming, scorching and killing of Hearbes, Plants, Trees, Fruites, and encrease of the earth, and is a likenes of death for the time; so is the Spring a renewing, quickning, and restoring of all things, as before.

By this Similie then we may obserue, that as sinne by man committed, is a benumming, wounding and killing of man, and is (as a Winter) death to man: So is Repentance as the Spring renewing, quickening, and raising of that man, a liuely image of his resurrection. And the Repentant thus reuiued, renued,
and raised againe, behold his Spring, hee putteth forth his blosomes, and bringeth forth fruites, namely workes worthy amendement of life.
The Spring we see giues a state, essence, and being to things: Noua rerum species, noua rerum facies: it reneweth the face of the whole earth▪ and so doth Repentance the whole man.
The Yeare is diuided into foure parts, and euery quarter is Trimensis, or Trimestris, that is, consisting of three Months: So likewise is the Spring diuided into three times or Seasons. viz.

list.item: Praeceps. The fading or falling Spring.

div.p: By the new Spring, we haue a new face vpon the earth, the dead, and darke mantle is taken away, and a liuely fresh vaile is put on: So is it in the Soules▪ Spring of Repentance, there is, Noua forma, Noua creatura, A new Creature, a new man; The ragged cloake of blind Bartimeus is put off, and the rich roabe, and wedding garment of Righteousnes and Holinesse is put on.

And thus much of the description of Repentance,
and now we come to the definition thereof.

div.head: Poenitentia, Repentance is,
div.p: The altring or changing of the former course of life: an inward sorrow and mourning for sinne ioyned with Faith, to obtaine remission; and amendment of life bringing forth fruits answerable to Repentance.
Whereby wee learne that the conuersion of a Sinner consisteth of three parts▪ viz.

list.item: 1. Of a purpose and resolution in the mind.
2. Of an inclinatiō & propension in the wil.
3. Of an indeauour and practise in the life, to abandon former sinnes, and to walke in obedience vnto Gods commandements.

div.p: But here it may be questioned, whether Faith be a part of Repentance, or no?

To which I answere, Repentance is a thing necessarily ioyned to Faith, but faith is no part thereof: for, if Repentance be taken (as heere we vnderstand it) for the restoring, returning, and renewing of mans life: then it is cleare, that repentance is the fruit of Faith, and Faith, no part of Repentance: example hereof.

As the body of the Sunne is one thing, and
the light another, distinct the one from the other, and yet the one capable of the other, so is Repentance, and Faith, distinct, and seuerall, one from the other, and yet crauing the vse, and helpe one of another.

Faith is the inchoation (and as it were) the mother of Repentance, and giueth light, to the man that minds to repent: for when the minde of man, begins to embrace the goodnesse of God, touching remission of sinnes, by the death of Christ; Then doth immediatly follow alteration, and renouation: that is, the casting away of the workes of darkenesse, and the puting on, of the armor of light. So then we conclude, Faith, is the initiation of Repentance; and Repentance, is the consummation of Faith. The essentiall parts of true Repentance are two, viz. 1. To cease from euill. 2 To endeuour to doe good. Psal. 34.

We must not onely eschew euill, but wee must also doe that which is good. The commandement that is there Prohibitiue, is there preceptiue also: & he that doth there enioine, doth there restraine also: hee that negatiuely forbiddeth what a man shall not doe, he affirmatiuely also cōmandeth what a man should doe. It is not enough for a man to shun euill,
but hee must also follow that which is good.

As touching the integrity of a Christian life, it is nothing at all mouere, except we doe promouere also▪ it is nothing to cast a way the workes of darknesse, except wee put on the Armour of light. Rom. 13. 12. It is nothing to mortifie the flesh, except we doe quicken the spirit. Gal. 5. 24. 26. It is nothing to renounce Adam, except we embrace Christ. Rom. 12. 2. Briefely, it is nothing to forsake vngodlines, and sinfull lusts, except we liue soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world. Titus, 2. 12. Qui non proficit, Deficit: Wee must therefore begin well, and end well too; wee must add strength to strength. By this then that hath beene spoken, the causes of repentance, are made conspicuous, viz. 1 the formall is our conuersion or change: 2 The matter, is the will of man resoluing: 3 The obiect, is our sinne, and good life: our sinne, for which wee are sorrow: our good life, which wee endeuour seriously to performe. 4 The principall efficient is God, and the adiuuant or instrumental cause is faith, God bestowing Faith, and Faith begetting Repentance. 5. The finall, is the honour, and glory of God, and the health & saluation of our soules. And thus much you haue heard of Repentance.
1. By way of discription. 2. By way of definition. 3. By euidence of the true causes thereof.

Now are we come to certain circumstances, and obseruances concerning Repentance: of which in order, the circumstances are in number foure viz. 1. The time, when to repent. 2. The meanes and motiues, mouing to repent. 3. The lets and hinderances, that wee cannot repent. 4. The griefe, and sorrow, wee must vndergoe, if we will truely repent; with other branches as pedisique attendants, and annexed rites and ceremonies, I mean penitenciall ceremonies.

div.head: For the first. Agenda est in tempore Poenitentia.
div.p: Repentance must be done in due, and fit time, all our life, should be the study of repentance, immediatly vpon any sinne committed, let our repentance be then practised, perscribe not to thy selfe in presumption, and lingering time of thy conuersion. It is the greatest of all follies, to deferre repentance, and to delay amendment of our sinfull life.
div.q:
Qui • odie non est, oras minus aptus erit.
If to day be too soone, to morrow will be too late.
Ecclus. 5. 7. Cras, Cras, to morrow, to morrow.
div.p: It is the voyce of the Crow, indeed, it is the voyce of the Deuill, it is a deadly voyce, sounded forth by our deadly enemy: For repentance admits no delay, doe that therefore out of hand, forthwith, euen now; euery hower of thy life, and at the last howre of thy death.
In youth begin well, lay a good foundation, hold on in thy midle age, and giue not ouer in thy latter end; for a presumptuous life, will neuer afford a prosperous death.
Ʋix millessimus (saith Salomon) scarce one of a thousand (a wofull and lamentable report) that by Repentance doth study, the amendment of his wicked life.

I am not ignorant, that Paenitentia, Repentance is Nunquam sera si sit seria, is neuer too late, if it be sincere; this stands assured by example of the Theefe. Luke 22. but take thou heed, the like grace may not be giuen thee, that was giuen and afforded him.
There is (saith reuerend Saint Austin) this one Example in the Scripture, that wee should not despaire, and no more but that one, that we should not presume.

Remember therefore (all that heare mee)
remember I say and forget not.

1. That as the tree falleth so it lyeth, Remember that. 2. That in Hell there is no redemption, Remember that. 3. That being once gone from hence, we are past recouery, Remember that. 4. That as death doth possesse vs, so the fearefull day will present vs, Remember that. 5. That we repent in this life before we die or neuer, Remember that.
Looke vpon the richman in Hell, Luke 16.
There is no deliuerance, no comming forth, no hope of a better life, but that kinde of fire which is intollerable (as some say) in truth incurable as many shall finde.

Clemens Alexandrinus, makes mention of a conference, betwixt Christ and the Deuill, (it is extant as hee affirmeth in the Aegyptian library, the most famous in all the world, founded by great Ptolomy the learned) The question was, When the Kingdome of God should come? The answere was, when the worke of the Woman should cease. Of these particularly and briefely.
And first, of the Kingdome of God.

The kingdome of Christ, and the kingdome of God, doe differ non re, sed modo rei,
not in the thing it selfe, but in the manner, and meanes thereof. The kingdome of Christ is said to be the Church, that is, the company of the faithfull and elect (whilst they be in this life) who are gathered together and gouerned by the spirit, the word and Sacraments, in which Christ is effectuall to begin a new life in righteousnesse and holinesse. Now this Church, and Kingdome of Christ, shalbe the Kingdome of God in the world to come, in the life eternall; at which time, the dispensation of the word, and Sacraments shall cease, when God will take away the vayle, and open himselfe vnto vs, that wee may see him as he is, face to face.
The Ground, Rule, and Maxime from hence to be learned, is this,

1. Be sure, that thou be a member of the Church Militant; if euer thou wilt be found in the Church Triumphant. 2. Take heed, that being once in, and of the Church, thou neuer practise seditiously to depart from the Church, or outragiously, Schismatically, or turbulently, to procure the molestation, trouble, vnquiet, or ouerthrow of the same. Cant. 3. 5. And thus of the Kingdome of God.

Secondly, of the worke of the woman.
The worke of the woman is three fould. viz.

And when these shall cease, then shall the Kingdome of God come. Of which in order. And first, of the first. One cause of the institution of Mariage, was for Procreation sake, Crescite, et multiplicamini. Gen. 1. 28.

But when this Kingdome of God, in most perfect beauty shall appeare, then shall Procreation cease, then no more vse of the Midwise, to helpe in the needfull time of trauell: for the wombe shalbe closed vp.
This was the determination, of our Sauious to the Saduces, that in that Kingdome, they neither marry, nor are married, but are as the Angells of God. Mat. 22. 30. And thus of the first.

The other worke of the Woman is sinne; and consequently by sinne death. For, first; Of the woman came the beginning of sinne, and through her we all die, Ecclus. 25. 26. Secondly, She tooke the fruit of the tree and did eate, and gaue to her husband, and he did eate also, Gen. 3. 6. Thirdly, Adam was not
deceiued, but the woman was deceiued, and was in the transgression. 1. Tim. 2. 14. For, as lands doe hold in capite, in respect of some speciall couenant of seruice: euen so doth sin hold in capite of the woman, as she being first deceiued, became the Deuils instrument, to deceiue the man. Let therefore all women from hence remember. First, their own weaknesse. Secondly, the ancient fall they gaue to man and his posteritie. Thirdly, that she is the former cause of Originall sinne, and of our corrupted and defiled nature. So then the time shall come that generation, and procreation shall cease, one worke of the woman: and the time shall come, that sinne, and death shall also cease, the proper worke of Eue, in mankind. For, the elect of God shall sinne no more: the Israell of God shall die no more, but shall be translated from death, to liue for euermore. Procreation, sin, and death, shall haue an end, and cease. In this world therefore, while we liue, let vs beleeue, and while we breathe let vs hope: This is the only place appointed, to lay hold on faith, and to leane on hope: for the time shall come, that faith, and hope also shall haue an end, and cease.

The difference betweene
Faith
Hope
Love is this,

Thy faith and hope, do end with the terme of thy life; but thy loue shall neuer haue an end. We loue in this life, and we shall still, and more perfectly loue in that life which is to come. Wouldst thou faine see the extent and perpetuitie of loue? looke then into the workes of Charitie.

If a man haue once fed the hungrie, or clothed the naked &c. hath he then done? hath he then his quietus est from God? I tell thee nay. For, in the workes of charitie, when man thinkes he hath made an end, he doth then but begin. the reason is pregnant: for loue hath no end, the end of our life, is not the end of our loue; the end of our loue in this life, is the beginning of a better loue in a beter life: but faith and hope doe cease when wee die, yet the fruit of faith and hope wee obtaine, though we be dead, and they departed.
Now briefly to recapitulate touching the first circumstance of the time when to repent; namely, in this life, or now, forthwith, without delay.

This hath also beene exemplified and enlarged by the kingdome of Christ & of God, wherein we haue learned. First, that in the one is the dispensation of the word, and administration of the Sacraments, but for a time: for they shall haue their end, and shall cease. Secondly, that the works of the woman, procreation, sin, and death, shal be but for a time, and shall haue an end, and they shall cease. Thirdly, saith, and hope also, for a season shall haue their bounds and limits, which they shal not passe, but haue their time, and shall cease. Fourthly, we thereby learne, that repentance hath also her lists and race, wherein she must run: namely the terme of this life, the daies of our Pilgrimage, and then hath her end, and shall cease. In this therefore as the Apostle counselleth, sic currite, vt comprehendatis, 1. Cor. 9.

And thus, God in mercie we beseech him graunt, that wee may so runne, that with the wings of faith, we may ascend to the Mount of God, and flye to his heauenly promises: and by the feete of repentance, we may not only goe from sinne, and vncleannesse, but also from punishment, and vengeance, Amen.
Concerning the meanes, and motiues, by which we are drawne to Repentance, which are in number foure, viz.

The first is, Punishment from God, in respect of sin in man. There is malum culpae, and malum poenae, one kind of euill which is sinne▪ and another, which is the reward of sin. The Lord is free and farre from sin, no author, no fautor, or actor thereof, but a sore reuenge • of sinne, and hater of all impietie.

Now, the sinne which we doe, is the cause of the punishment we suffer: whether it be priuate or publike, which notwithstanding God gratiously vseth as meanes, and motiues, to win vs to repentance. No man euer was▪ or shall be punished, but in respect of precedent sinne: but wheresoeuer God findeth sin there he punisheth it seuerely.

The house of Dauid is summoned to judgement, 2. Sam. 12. And it is (if rightly considered) a looking-glasse to all posterities, to see and behold by, what is, and shall be the reward of sinne. Dauid, though otherwise a man after Gods owne heart and dearely beloued, yet committing sinne with Beersheba.
First, the childe so conceiued dieth the death, Secondly, his whole postaritie doth smart for it. Thirdly, his children lawfully begotten, some are slaine with the sword, some rebell against their Father, some shamefully defloured, and some of them killed one of another. Fourthly, his wiues foully rauished, in the sight of the Sun, and in the face of all Israell. Fiftly, the sword was not to depart from his house for euer. So then we see, there is no misery matchable with that, which God inflicteth vpon man for sinne. A grieuous thing it is for a man to be punished in his wife which is his side, in his children which are his loynes, in his seruants who are his armes, hands, legs, and feete, or in his goods which be as a chaine, and ornament about his neck: and yet for sinne, a man is smitten in all these; yea, and in himselfe also most miserably. Yet notwithstanding all this, if he haue grace so to interpret them, they are all sanctified meanes, and motiues to repentance.
A Question may heere be moued, viz.

Why punishment should be executed, notwithstanding the offence is perdoned: for this indeed was Dauids case, pronounced by Nathan? I answere: These punishments from
God, haue a two-fold effect, according to the two-fold different qualitie, of the godly, and wicked.

list.item: 1. To the godly, they tend to their information, and correction only.
2. To the wicked, they are seuere punishments, tending to their ruine, and destruction only. And to the godly, they serue as thunder-bolts, viz▪

div.p: First, to awake the drowsie sinner. Secondly, that being awake, he might thereby be pricked on, to vnfeyned Repentance.

And as to the righteous, they are alwaies tokens of mercie; so to the wicked, they are scales of wrath, and judgement: for, to the godly, they are, and serue as: first, exercises of Faith: secondly, trials of Patience: thirdly, proofes of Gods Iustice: fourthly, examples of Instruction, thereby to teach them, to beware for the future, seeing Gods wrath is already kindled. The conclusion then is, that by Repentance, temporall punishments are sometimes deferred, sometime mitigated, sometime remoued, and assuredly at all times remitted.

The second motiue is Feare, for feare doth keepe vs in moderation and awe, I meane not
the seruile, the feare of slaues, but the filiall, the feare of sonnes: not in the respect of the vengeance, the reward of sinne, but in respect of the offence, for committing of sinne. Whereo •
• ertull▪ sweetely saith, vbi metus uullus ibi emendatio nulla, & vbi emendatio nulla ibi poenitentia vana. Where this filiall, reuerend, vertuous, and religious feare is not, there can be no heartie, and true amendment, and where this true amendment is not, there (let the outward shew be neuer so great) the Repentance is but hypocriticall and vaine. And yet both good and bad (as the Poet saith) oderunt, they both feare, yea and peccare, they both scare to sinne too; but diuersly affected, the one sort formidine poenae, for feare of seueritie, the other, virtutis amore, For loue of vertue, and this onely restreyneth the godly from sinne; namely, not for feare of vengeance, but for loue and reuerence.

A third motiue to Repentance is, the quick and liuely remembrance of sinne: for a sinner (as I noted) is a heauie and drowsie sleeper. Example heereof Ionas, who was a sleepe in the sides of the Ship, while judgement was at hand to cast him ouer board. Dauid also
may instance this point, who slept in his sinne the space of a whole yeare; his conscience neuer checkt him, till judgements were like to choake him.

A senselesse securitie i 〈…〉 to feele the sting of sinne, nor to feare the wrath of Gods displeasure. The remembrance of sinne in man, doth cause the forgetfulnesse of sinne in God: so againe, the forgetfulnesse of sinne in man, doth cause the remembrance of sinne in God.

Yea, by this remembrance of sinne, wee put in practise a sacred preuention of Gods judgements; for when he purposeth to strike a sinner, if he see man by repentance altered, the Lord is changed; he doth v • bend his bowe case his arrowes, sheath his sword, and lay aside all his instruments of reuenge, because he is slow to anger, readie to forgiue, full of pittie and compassion; if thou by repentance be altered, he is changed. And this vse of the remembrance of our sinnes is full of sweet and fruitfull consolation.

For we must deale with our sinnes, as men deale with their debts, (which for suretiship they haue payd) when they take in their bonds, and euidences and cancell them, they
will not therefore burne them, though they be neuer more lyable to be paid; but will file and hang them vp in their continuall sight, that whensoeuer they shall be moued to enter into the like debt, and trouble againe, they may by the sight thereof be put in minde, into what vexation and danger, they were formerly plunged, that thereby they may shunne, and auoyd the like, for the time to come, and giue non plus, and resistance, to those that tempt and importune them therevnto.

A fourth motiue is, the Preaching of the word. Now, the word is deuided, into the Law and Gospell. And in this question as touching the most powerfull instrument of the holy Ghost, in working repentance: some hold the Law, and some the Gospell to be the chiefe meanes, instrument, or motiue therevnto. For my part, I doe suppose them to be both so necessary, as neither of them doe good without each other in the worke of Repentance. For the Preaching of the Law alone, doth breed desperation: and the Preaching of the Gospell alone, may quicken presumption, the two dangerous gulfes, Silla and Charibdis.

Therefore there is neither of them both, but hath a proper vse, in the mistery of Repentance. A resemblance hereof; as, in Phisicke the skilfull Artist, intending to purge the grosse humors of a corrupted body, doth first vse some Electuary or Preparatory Potion, to serue as meanes to prepare the body, and to make it fit to receiue the medicine Purgatiue: So, the terrours, and threatnings of the Law, are answerable, to the Phisitians Preparatory, and doth as it were make ready the way, by opening of the heart, to receiue Repentance.

The end of the law, is to discouer sinne. Rom. 7. 7. For there is in man before the law, an ignorance, and sencelesnesse of sinne, hee feeles not the poyson, that feedeth on his soule to his distruction.

The law doth Sacrifice a man to God, and makes him poore in Spirit, and humble in himselfe, to see his corruption and sinne. The Gospell promiseth to saue, but it doth not performe this promise, but to such onely, whom the law hath thus Sacrificed to Christ.

Christ calleth sinners, but such onely, as are laden with their sinnes. Mat. 11. 28. Hee cryeth to such as thirst, Come▪ Esay. 40. 1.
Reu. 22. 17. But yet to such onely, as thrst, as Dauid did. Psa. 42. 1. & Psal. 63. 2.

The Gospell is not to be Preached to any, before he be Ch • istened by the Law, that is, before the Law hath done her proper worke. Let Ministers therfore first schoole their people by the Law, before they rayse them by the Gospell.
It is necessary, the law should goe before the Gospell. The sons of thunder, before the sonnes of comfort, that then, when the law hath wounded them, the Gospell may cure and heale.

The Law cannot quiet the conscience of man, it was not ordained to that purpose, it serueth to present to the eie of our soule, our dangerous state, and to smite our conscience with terrour, and feare, then commeth the Gospell, and falleth to worke (when the law hath done this) assuring man, that his saluation consisteth, in Remissione Peccatorum, in the forgiuenesse of sinne by Christ. He that is ignorant of the law, knoweth neither what misery is in himselfe, nor what mercy is in God. We Preach iudgement, to make men sue for mercy, to make them cry for mercy; for merit they haue none, we Preach death
and damnation, to bring sinfull soules to saluation. But to Preach mercy, and saluation, before men see their sinnes, and feele their misery, is to Preach the Gosp • ll in vayne, and to no purpose.
The Law hath her time and place, her time How long, and place where to Raigne.

By the raigning of the Law, is meant, the condemnation of the Law: Now this Law ceaseth to raigne that is, to condemne, when faith in a true repentant heart, is once begun. For the law hath no place, in the repentant, and amending man. And thus of the second Circumstance.

div.head: The third Circumstance is,
div.p: The lets, and hinderances, whereby wee are withdrawen, from fruitfull repentance: For euidence whereof, the raising of the widdowes sonne of Naim. Luke 7. 11. If it please you, that I breefly Paraphrase it by an Alegory (as the Fathers haue done) it will afford much light therevnto, as thus:
1. The mother, doth represent the Church, bewailing the death of her children.
2. The sonne, doth liuely figure, the estate of sinfull soules, who though they seeme to liue in body, yet are they dead in soule by sin.

3. The foure Beaters are these, viz. first, hope of long life: secondly, long custome in sinne: thirdly, contempt of Gods word: fourthly, worldly prosperity: All which being well considered, will proue shrewd lets to repentance. And of them all, I know none, that beareth greater sway then wealth, and worldly prosperity. Of which I will onely insist, in stead of the rest: for oftentimes, it doth bewitch man, as the Cups of Circes, and makes him drunke, in the forgetfulnesse of God, and amendment of his life.
One of the Fathers saith, that of prosperity, ariseth all • xcesse, and superfluity, and that from thence, doth spring all vice, and impiety against God.

Seneca saith, that by too much prosperity, the mind is hardned, and therefore, Saint Paul bids Timothy to charge rich men, not to be high minded. Saint Iames doth wake their heauy heads, and drousie hearts, with a dolefull Elegie: Weepe, and howle, yee Richmen. Iames 5. 1. There is a deadly sleepe of security, and sleepe to death, in flowing prosperity.

Call to mind the Purpuled Richman, who being dead, was quickly conueyed to hell; a
fearefull change. Another Richman, in Luke, 12. who, vpon a litle extraordinary spring, he was at his wits end, and knew not what to doe: for gaping for a plentifull haruest, hee would doe this, and that, 〈◊〉 you may reade, but by death preuented, he was answered, (as all such godlesse and graceles rich ones shall) Stulte, hac nocte, a sudden and sore change.
The iudgement of our Sauiour, as our close shall therefore stand, Mat. 19. 23. That it is hard indeed, for a wicked rich man, to enter into the Kingdome of Heauen. And thus of the third Circumstance.

div.head: The fourth and last Circumstance is.
div.p: The griefe, and sorrow, which we are to vndergoe, if we will truely repent; together with certaine rites, and ceremonies necessarily belonging to vnfayned repentance, to which purpose here in this Woman three things are principally markeable, viz.
First, Her weeping, an euident argument of her feare, and dread of conscience, for her sinne.
Secondly, Her comming to Christ: an assured argument of her faith, and hope, which she had of the remission of her sinne.

Thirdly, Her actions, viz. 1. At the instant,
2. Afterwards: vndoubted testimonies of her duty, and loue▪ per modum obedientiae, non per modum satisfactionis, in way of obedience, not of sufficiency, or satisfaction, as the Papists say.

So that he that thinketh seriously and aduisedly, of the repentance of Mary Magdalen, may rather weepe in remembrance of it, then deliuer any discourse of it. What stony heart would not this soften? to see those flouds of teares, that sea of sorrow, and to heare those deepe sighes, and farre fetched groanes infallible signes of vnfayned repentance.

Obserue I pray you, the Circumstance of time, inter epulas lachrimas, when others were feasting, then was she weeping, so feeding on the bread of teares, and had plenteousnesse of teares to drinke, Psa 80. 5. In this her lamentable Repentance, how great signes shee shews, et fidei, et charitatis, both of faith and loue. By which teares of repentance, shee seemes to breake the very strings of her hart.
Dolor est comes poenitentiae, et lachrimae sunt testes doloris, saith Saint Austin; teares are witnesses of true sorrow, as griefe is the companion of Repentance.
In Repentance a man must vse seuerity against himselfe, that being iudged of himselfe, he be not condemned of the Lord, 1. Cor. 11. 31.

Therefore, as this poore woman here doth, so let vs send our Embassadors to God before vs; namely, our teares, sighes, and groanes, our threefould Cable, powrefull with God: being all outward actions, expressing our inward affections. Wherein, as Saint Bernard saith, in quantum non peperceris tibi, in tantum cred • mihi, Deus tibi parcit, in how little, thou doest spare thy selfe in thy repentance, beleeue me, by so much the more God will spare thee. For a broken, and contrite heart (full fraught with sorrow,) is a sacrifice to God. Psal. 51. 17.
Sorrow towards God worketh Repentance to Saluation, but sorrow of the world bringeth death. 2. Cor. 7. 10.
The heauinesse of the godly in Repentance doth differ from the sorrow of the wicked, though both are sorrowfull.
1. The Godly, for that by sinne they haue offended God.
2. The wicked, for feare of punishment, not for feare of the offence.

But heerein the vnspeakeable goodnes of Almighty God, doth plentifully appeare, in turning the griefe and sorrow of the godly, into cheerefull▪ and gladsome ioy: according to his owne gracious promise. Iohn 16. 22.
For God indeede doth comfort all true repentant sinners,

What vnfaigned repentance was there euer without sorrow, weeping, mourning, Sackcloth, and ashes, humbling our selues before God: For these are proper, and necessary branches thereof, which if they be vsed in sincerity and simplicity, and not in dissembled, Popish, perfunctory hypocrisie, they euer were, now are, and alwayes will bee, acceptable to God.
And the godly hauing thus farre entred into Repentance by confession, they continue therin by contrition and shedding of teares, as for example.
The People of Israell, beeing sharply rebuked by the Angell Iudg. 2. 4. they cryed and wept, and called the name of the place Bochim, a fletu, et gemitu, of sorrow and sighing.
The mourning of Dauid in his bed,
The weeping of Ionas in the Whales belly,
The mourning and cry of rhe Niniuites,
The bitter Repentance of Peter, and
The salt teares of Mary Magdalen, doe clearly expresse.
The griefe of a true repentant Sinner is compared to the paines and pangs of a woman in trauaile.

Inexpressible indeede are the passions of Child-birth, and little ioy is there to the poore patient, till the Child bee borne, and then shee reioyceth to see her owne fruit so much dersired, which lay so secretly in the wombe, a bed of darkenesse: Euen so, the griefe of Repentance (which is excessiue great) is qualified with the mixture of ioy and comfort, to behold the sweet fruit of his
trauell, Newnes of lise.
This is a mournefull Elegie, and dolefull Song.
To eat thy bread like Ashes, and mingle thy drinke with thy teares. Psal. 102.

Dauid there seemes in respect of the aboundant sorrow, required in Repentance, to change euen the course of Nature: For Homo is Animal sociabile, created for society: but now by Repentance, (so sore affected with griefe, hee shunneth company, hee delighteth in no society, but assimulateth himselfe to a Pelican in the wildernesse, an Owle in the Desert, and is like a Sparrow, that sitteth alone vpon the house toppe.
And thus of the Circumstances.
Now briefely of the rites, and ceremonies expressing true Repentance, as these that follow, and such like.
To knock our hard and stony hearts with the Publican. Luke 18.
To smite thy thigh. Ier. 31. 18.
To teare the haire. 2. Sam. 13.
Tow wring and smite the hands. Ezech. 21.
To rent the garments. Esay, 37.
To frequent solitary places. Esay. 2.
To lye vpon the ground. Dan. 10.
To put on Sackcloth. Ionah 3.
To strew Ashes. Iob. 42.
To proclaim solemne & publike fasts. Io. 2.
Ie • unare, to fast. Ier. 14.
Vlulare, to howle. Ier. 15.
And thus of the Rites, and Ceremonies.
Now we come to the obseruances, and speciall markable things, in and about Repentance.

div.head: The first Obseruation.
div.p: The last furtherance, and helpe to Repentance (which we noted) was the Preaching of the word, which is the power of God to saluation. Rom. 1. 16. for, where Prophesie faileth, there the people perish. Prou. 19. 18.
A notable meane indeed, to bring men to Repentance, is the
A singular thing it is indeed, to haue worthy men in the Church, able to teach and instruct, to inuite and intreat to Repentance.
Oh, but where is Origen, who was called Magister Ecclesiarum, the great Maister of the Church? Where is S. Basill, that was surnamed, Canon fidei, the rule of Faith?
Where is Euse ••• s, that was stiled Regula Veritatis, the standard of truth?
And where now is Athanasius, that was termed, Orbis oculus, the eye of the world? Oh, where shall wee finde them?

I doe not speake this, as though the Church of God, yea this Church in England (in despite of all malignants, that traduce it) were without such singular instruments; for I doe assuredly know, that this Church at this day (God haue the praise) is as well furnished with learned men, as any of the reformed Churches in all the World: as I can also shew and proue, by the letters commendatory from beyond the Seas, and by their workes dedicated to diuers, of our learned Bishops. Yet with griefe I doe bewaile, to finde in many places, the Lords crop to be so superseminated, and ouer sowne with tares, godlesse, and vnprofitable persons.
Wee haue also swarmes of locusts, Pharises, Saduces, Athiests.

Pharises, who swell in conceipt of their
owne Righteousnes, Iustciaries, ambitious hypocrites, who bragge of that they haue not, and would seeme to bee what indeede they are not.

Saduces, Libertines, and Atheists, wh • deny the resurrection of the dead, with othe • principles of faith and Religion, yea they cal • into question Gods truth in his word, who beleeue not there is either God, Spirit, Angell, or iudgement to come, and therefore they say and doe what they list; these make a scoffe at Religion, and a very iest of true Repentance.

div.head: The 2. Obseruation is,
div.p: As Faith is supposed to haue wings, and Repentance to haue feet: and as the natural man in committing sinne, doth deface the Image of God, and in feare for sinne, doth goe from God, doth flye from God; So doth he againe by Repentance make a stop. It isnot the least property and point in the managing of a horse, to bring him to his stop▪ A Repentant man making his stop, goes no • further, yea he reteynes himselfe, and goes no • further.

In this place, Repentance signifies, to turn • againe, and so the Repentant now turne •
againe to God from whom by sinne he fled: witnesse the Prodigall Sonne, who after a serious consultation, he grew to a religious resolution, and so to an effectuall, and vertuous execution: with
〈◊〉 , redibo and so by turning from his course he followed, he came to his father, from whom he fled. Luke 15.
So by this stop, and turning againe, the Repentant auoideth the wrath to come, which none can doe, but Alis fidei & pedibus poenitentiae, by the wings of faith, and feete of Repentance onely.

div.head: The 3. Obseruation.
div.p:
Is it possible for an old, aged, gray-headed man, drooping, and stooping for age, that he may be said to be but three yeares old when he is three times 30. yeares old? Yet such a one we read of, who so auouched: when question was demanded how this might be? Hee answered thus: three yeares agoe (saith hee) I was with Zacheus in the Fig-tree, with Mathew at the receipt of Custome, with the Prodigall sonne in afarre Country, and with Mary Magdalen at the feete of Christ, I was thē (saith he) as vile as vile may be, but by the grace of God, and hearing of his word, by faith and true Repentance I am now another
man, tanto mutatus, as farre changed as you now see: for Repentance is transformatiue, and doth alter a man: It is (saith hee) three yeares since God wrought this miracle in me, (a miracle indeed) and 〈…〉 e I am, and no older, for before I was nothing at all.

div.head: The fourth Obseruation.
div.p: A shame it is for Christians, if the name, and Gospell of Christ, be euill spoken of through their irreligious, and dissolute liues, Can Iewes, Turkes, Infidels be perswaded that there is any goodnesse, in that Religion, the professors whereof are so vile, and prophane? and yet we know, that none of vs can be ordered otherwise, vnlesse God grace preuent vs, his spirit guide vs, and true repentance possesse vs, we are naturally so apt, to all sinne, and disobedience.

Therefore, as our Sauiour Christ once questioned, concerning the Scribes and Pharises, whereunto he might liken, or compare them, and presently answered himselfe; so may that answere be fitly said of men now a daies, that they are as stubborne Children in the market place stubborne, and foolish too, Luc. 7. 3. who though we pipe, yet they wil not dance, though we weepe, yet they will not mourne.

This woman was wealthie, and very rich, but very leude, and dishonest. Nore heere, that wealth will haue a veine to shew it selfe; as some in appare •• , some in building, some in feasting, some in oppressing, some in coueting, and some in vncleane and filthie lusting, as in this rich woman before her conuersion.
But after her conuersion, she had a better vent, a better veine to shew her wealth, and that was Ministrare Christo, to minister to Christ, and his necessities.
Let rich men and women, heerein imitate this worthy Marie Magdalen, to shew their wealth in supplying the wants of Christ his Ministers, and poore members.

div.head: The sixt Obseruation.
div.p:
Seneca (as it seeme▪) borrowed some light from a Christians practise, in the examination of his life, in the darke, and dead of the night, concerning thoughts, and deeds committed the day before, as Dauid saith Psal. 77. 6. I call to remembrance &c. and so saith Seneca, faciebat hoc Sextius consumante die, cum se ad nocturnam quietem recepisset, he would demand of himselfe thus, Sextius, what good hast thou done to day? what euill hast thou
cured? what sinne hast thou resisted? in what art thou altered?

Oh beloued, what better practise, then this accompt? what better sleepe, then after such examination? When the candle is put out, then call the day that is past to a reckoning: If thou hast done any thing well, giue God the praise, for it was his gift: if any thing amisse, then call to God for grace and pardon, but couch not thy head vpon thy pillow to take thy rest, before thou haue thy quietus est from him.

div.head: The seuenth Obseruation.
div.p: When Christ came into the World, there were two softs of people, some were blinde, and some could see. There were some foolish, and some wise. Christ by his comming did not make them so, but at his comming found them so.

There was then also, a two-fold wisedome in the World, one which the Sonne of God found heere, and another which he brought with him. Consider then, and marke heere well I pray you, in this doctrine of Repentance, so often Preached vnto you, obserue and note, how the Gospell findeth you, and how the Gospell leaueth you.

There is a Prouerb among the Latins, that frons homin • m praefert, the fore-head shewes, what the man is. Frons (as Marcus Varro saith) commeth a foratu, of boaring, because the eye-hoales, are as it were boared throughy the fore-head.
It seemeth then by this Etimologie, that the eye sheweth the man. The waterie eye indeed, is a great signe of Repentance.

The eyes be fores and fenestrae animi, the doores and windowes of the minde: by which we take view, looke, and prye into the minde, heart, and conscience of man: and by which affections are open and made manifest, how in the minde, or inwardly he stands affected: merrie or sorrie, angrie or pleased, well in his wits or out, foolish or wise, chast or vnchast, drunken or sober, humble or proud, innocent or guiltie, repentant or not; the eye will tell it, the eye will bewray it.
Thus haue we finished, and perfected, according to our wish, and intention our purposed discourse of Repentance.

div.head: Many sinnes are forgiuen her, for she loued much.
div.p: THere is yet somewhat more to be spoken of this Text, for there is something that may be taken amisse in the vnderstanding thereof. The coniunction or word in the Greeke translated 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in the Latin, quia, or quoniam, & in English, because, or for, is in this place Nota illatiua not causalis, it is not a note causall, but a note illatiue, or a note of inference, as a sequell, not as a causall▪ for it is not heere, argumentum a causa, but ab effectu: and that no other sence than this can heereof be gathered, the words themselues, doe expresse. For proofe whereof, obserue how the Parable is propounded, of two debtors, indebred to one creditor; one in one thousand, the other in ten thousand: which neither of them being able to pay, the Creditor forgaue them both.
The Question from this case is, which of these two, will loue him most? The answere is, The partie to whom he forgaue most.

Then the solution of our Sauiour could in effect be no otherwise than this: I haue forgiuen her much; therefore she loueth me much.
So that heere we see, that loue is the sequell of forgiuenesse of sinnes, and forgiuenesse of sinnes no consequent of loue. For, the forgiuenesse of her sinnes went before, and her loue followed after. It is impossible, with any thing to please God without Faith, Heb. 11. 6 much lesse with loue without Faith. And yet that which is more, and wonderfull too, wee can not please God with Faith, without loue, 1. Cor. 13. 2. and yet for all this, loue cannot justifie vs. The loue of God is the efficient cause of Righteousnesse, which by faith only we apprehend.

So God loued the World (and then it followes) that he which beleeueth &c. Obserue heere, how the Loue of God goeth before; the Faith of man giueth attendance, and the loue of man commeth after. Our loue that pleaseth God, must be the fruit and effect of faith: and this is so acceptable in the persons justified, as that they be of no accompt without it. Charitas est testimonium iustificantis fidei: Loue is the true testimonie of justifying Faith.

But heere we must speake of Loue with a distinction: For all loue doth not justifie, though there be a loue that doth justifie,
whereof we reason thus, God doth justifie: But God is loue: Ergo, Loue doth justifie, I answere, it is true, if we speake of that loue wherewith God doth loue vs, dilecti in dilecto: but it doth not follow, th • t therefore our loue doth justifie. Hee that loues, fulfilleth the Law: but he that fulfils the Law, shall be justified: Ergo, he that loueth shall be justified. I grant it, if wee loue in that perfection as to fulfill the Law, wee shall be justified by our Loue.

But this was the priuiledge of Christ only, who loued in that measure of height, and depth of perfection, that hee fulfilled the whole Law by a voluntarie Sacrifice and free will offering of himselfe for vs: but as for vs▪ by reason of inherent sinne in vs, we cannot so loue.

Now, if h • ere you will aske this question, why God gaue man such a Law, as he in no wise can performe, fulfill, and keepe; and so seeme by consequent to imply, and conclude something thereby. I answere, First, almightie God in giuing man a Law, did respect what man should do, not what he could doe. Secondly, that God in giuing such a Law; made it equall to his owne righteousnesse
not to mans weakenesse. Thirdly, that man before his fall, was so created, made and endowed with such integrity, that he could if he would, haue stood, and fulfilled the law; but after sinne was once committed, he could not.

Behold then here, the great mistery of Gods great mercy in the depth of mans great misery. For, he sent his Sonne to take our nature vpon him: who in that nature, hath loued God aboue all, and his neighbour (man kind) as himselfe, and so hath made vp our breach, and thus we see, that the law is fulfiled in vs, though not by vs.

So then we conclude, that loue indeed doth iustifie vs, being passiuely vnderstood, Intelligendo dilectionem, qua nos, a deo diligimur, meaning, by that loue, wherewith God hath loued vs: but being actiuely taken, for that loue that is in our selues, that is so lame, weak, and imperfect, in the discharge of our duty, both to God and our neighbour, that the sentence of the law must needs passe against vs, and we stand guilty of eternall death, if the promise of life, and comfort of the Gospell did not reuiue, and relieue vs: First by Faith obtayned, secondly, by loue expressed. For as repentance
is two fould, viz. First essentiall, and secondly declaratiue, essentiall wrought by faith: declaratiue expressed by loue.
So also absolution from sin is two fould. viz. First, effectuall obtayned by faith: secondly, demonstratiue, • xpressed by the works of loue.

First, the effectuall absolution is inward, of the conscience, before God, and this is properly of Faith. And therefore our Sauiour turnes him to the woman, and assureth her of a release, a discharge, a quieta est, saying, stay thy selfe; thy conscience may be setled, depart in peace, thy faith hath made thee whole.

Secondly, the demonstratiue absolution, and remission from sinne is Publike, and requireth externa testimonia operum, to make manifest this conuersion; and therefore our Sauiour turnes him to the Pharisie, rehearsing the loue and workes of Mary, as sequels, and fruits of her faith, namely her washing, anoynting, wiping and kissing, &c.
So also we read of Zacheus: Halfe my goods I giue to the poore. Againe in the Acts of the Apostles, They brought their bookes of curious Art and burned them.

And so doth Mary Magdalen here, giue testimony of the remission of her sinnes before
God by faith, before the world by loue. The remission of sinne is such a thing, as without it none can be saued, and once hauing obteined it, none such can perish.
There was a Temple in Athens, which was called the Temple of Mercy, but they say, it is now translated to Rome, there onely is the propiciatory or mercy seate, that is now the onely place.
So that we are here set to schoole to learne to read, what S. P. Q. R. doth signifie: It was wont to be translated, Senatus Populus{que} Romanus: The Senate and people of Rome.

But now it meaneth some other thing, and I take it thus, Stultus Populus Quaerit Romam. A foolish people trudge to Rome. And wherefore? For mercy. And wherein? to obtaine Remission of sinnes. Where as, First they them selues know, that none can forgiue sins, but God onely.
Secondly, we our selues know, that mercy in forgiuenesse of sins, is not purchased with Indian gould.

Thirdly, and al lthe world beside doth know, that there is no mercy to be had at Rome, without mony, No mony, no mercy, no peny, no Pater noster: Si nihil attuleris, If
you be empty fisted, farewell and adeiu.
And therefore I still confidently conclude as before, Stultus Populus Quaerit Romam.

A fit motto for such vaine heads. There is the same reason, for remission of sinnes, as for the forgiuing of a debt; who hath I pray you, any title or interest in the debtor, but the creditor, he only is to demand, and to discharge.
We offend almighty God two waies, viz.
First immediatly by our breach of the commandements of the first table.
Secondly, mediatly by our breach of the commandements of the second table.

And hee takes the transgression of the second table, for Crimen lesae Maiestatis, as an hie offence because done against his commandements, and so we stand indebted vnto him: and in him, as in the Creditor, it wholy lyeth to forgiue.
But here we must knowe, that power to remit sinne is three fould. viz.
First Authoritatis, absOlutely of God.
Secondly, Min • sterii, being delegated to the ministers by assignement from God.

Thirdly, Priuati cuius{que} iuris, common and belonging to euery one that is iniured: for they haue a power to forgiue, yea they haue a
duty to forgiue by coōmandement from God.

The first of these is acknowledged, without all contradiction, for wee must haue recourse to God, both for our faults and punishments: for he is the party offended, and hee onely hath power to forgiue by absolute authority. Psal. 51. Against thee onely haue. &c.

What Angell in Heauen, what man on earth or Diuell in Hell, dares giue to any other this part of his right? The reason: for hee that must forgiue the sinnes of man, and cleare the conscience of the offender, must be such a one as seeth and beholdeth the heart, and secret thoughts: and such a one is God only.

Wherin ye must vnderstand, that the priuildge of the Church, wherewith God hath graced, and endowed it, is the forgiuenes of sinnes, the chiefe treasure thereof: which authority is assigned to the Ministers of the Church, namely to forgiue sinnes, by reason of their Ministry, in preaching and pronouncing of the forgiuenesse of sinnes, to them which beleeue, and repent: but indeed to be freed from the guiltinesse of sinne, is not in their power, but rests in the onely, proper, and absolute power of God.
The Keyes of the Kingdome of Heauen bee a chrage from God to preach forgiuene • of sinnes, and so to open the gate of eterna • life to the people.
To binde and to loose is the effect of preaching, which to them that beleeue turnes to their saluation, a suor of life; but to the vnbeleeuers, to their condemnation, a sauor o • death.
The Apostles were appointed instrument to preach this: Mercy and Iudgement, Mercy to the repentant, Iudgement to the impenitent.
Where the word is preached, if Repentance follow, then remission of sinnes must needs follow also.
In remission of sinnes Repentance is ioyned with Faith, not that by the worthines of Repentance remission is obtained, but by the merit of Christ, which by Faith onely is apprehended.
The keyes notwithstanding did hee commend to his Apostles, whereby they either open or shut the Kingdome of Heauen.

Which Keyes or Key rather, is as Chrisostome saith Scientia Scripturarum, the right knowledg of the Scripture, as Tertullian saith,
Interpretatio legis, the true interpretation of the Law: as Eusebius saith, Ʋerbum Dei, that this Key is no other then the word of God.

The word of God indeed is the right key, whereby as S. Ambrose saith, Remittuntur peccata, sinnes indeed are forgiuen: Which word of God, according to the diuers properties and effects thereof hath diuers names and titles in the Scripture. viz.
1. In that it multiplyeth and increaseth it is called Seed. Math. 13.
2. In that it cutteth and deuideth the heart and thoughts, it is called a Sword. Heb. 4.
3. In that it taketh and incloseth vs, it is called a Net. Math. 13.
4. In that it washeth, or clenseth, it is called Water. Heb. 10. 22.
5. In that it heateth and inflameth, it is called Fire. Mat. 3. 11.
6. In that it nourisheth and feedeth, it is called Bread. Math. 15.
7. In that it openeth or giueth entrance into the house it is called a Key. Mat. 16.
In which Metaphor of a Key, we are to obserue these perticulers. viz.
1. That the house is the Kingdome of Heauen. Ioh. 14.
2. That the doore of this house is the Lor • Iesus. Ioh. 10.
3. That the Word is the Key that openeth, interpreteth, and expresseth this doore Math. 16.
4. That the interpreter and expounder this word is the Priest. Mal. 2.

So that Christ giues the vse of this Key to the Ministers of the Gospell: but the Prerogatiue Royall, and the possession thereof hee keepeth to himselfe, and he properly, truely, and onely openeth, and no man shutteth, and shtteth and no man openeth. Apoc. 3. 7▪ And this authority which he giueth to them is to discouer sinnes, and vpon Repentance in his name to forgiue sinnes.

Take a figure hereof out of the old Law, the Leuiticall Priest did not make a Leper nor being one did clense him: hee did only declare, and determine, that if the party were infected, he should then be secluded the congregation; and being once clensed, he should pronounce him fit to bee receiued in againe; the same authority is also all one with vs.
There is great fault found with our Booke of Common prayer in this respect.

It is the obiect and subiect of many idle discourses, amongst many idle and shallow braines, who ignorantly, falsly, and maliciously affirme, that the Leaper, the sicke, the sinner, is assoyled, absolued, and pardoned, by the Priest, the Minister, the Preacher.
Now what (I pray you consider) is there in this whole action, which is not to be tollerated by equall and reasonable men, if they were not beyond measure giuen to contention.
If the Minister be sent for, it is his part to come, looke vpon the title De consolandis aegro • ātibus) yet for the most part we know that as he is the last sent for, so is hee the least welcome.
Well, we come to the sick mans house, to his chamber, to his bed, to his sick heart, where wee finde three readie attending on him: viz.

Well let them search his Cofers, for wee must sound his Conscience, & see what coyne and treasure is there. If we see a tryall of his faith, and an assurance of his hope, a taste
of his Repentance, and an Argument of his loue, oh let vs say so much, if we see so much, and out of Gods word to fetch a warant, and comfort to assure this sicke man, of the mercies of God, and remision of his sinnes by Christ.
I will make the case, or resemblance hereof.

A Malefactor that hath transgressed the Law, and is arraigned, condemned, and to be executed, if a pardon bee procured, and brought by some one therevnto assigned: I pray you tel men, who doth forgiue this offender, the Prince or the messenger?
We are but Messengers, we doe but bring the pardon from the Prince, The King of Kings, and we haue warrant out of the word for our so doing: yet with this prouiso: viz. so that it be done.

list.item: 4. With assured euidence of the sicke mans sincerity.
6. Or partiall respect to the party.

div.p:
And this remission of sinnes, is necessary
to bee looked vnto of vs all, namely, by what meanes we are saued, and freed from the same. For, this is our case, we are all indited, and must appeare to the action, and that in our owne person, not by Attorney.

We are all summoned; the writ is alreadie come forth, and cannot be retourned with non est inuentus, we must be at a minutes warning, vnder the great sub poena, of the forfeiture of bodie and soule. The action is of high-Treason against the King of Heauen, for that most rebelliously, disloyally, and trayterously we haue forsaken him our onely King, to serue a forraine Prince, his enemie; and this case, is not to be heard in Westminster Hall, before the Lord chiefe Iustice: but it must be heard aboue, in the high Court of the Starre-Chamber, before the assembly of the glorious Angels, before the Lord chiefe Iustice of the whole earth, and before the Lord high Chauncellor of the whole world. We must appeare to the action, we must stand to the answere, and abide the award. From which there is no appeale.

Our accuser is the Deuill, what is the cause? The breach of Gods Law, heere is no counterfeit deeds, nor forged euidences, our
consciences are the witnesses, therefore we must now looke to our selues, and seeke for as good stuffe to answere the matter withall for our discharge, as is brought against vs for our accusation, or else there is no remedie we perish. The profe is too true, which is brought against vs, wee are indebted to almightie God, satisfaction must be made, to the vttermost farthing, or else there is no remedie, we perish. Iustice must proceed, the law wil haue hir course; oh poore soules, now let vs looke what to answere, and that sufficiently, or else, there no remedie, we perish.
Well deare Christians, comfort your hearts, and with chearefull confidence answere thus.

Christ and his Church, is as man and his wife all one, he is the husband, and we the wife, he hath taken our nature vpon him, and by it, and with it, he doth communicate his owne person to vs, he is become flesh of our flesh, and bone of our bones substantially, and wee are become flesh of his flesh and bone of his bones spiritually. So that what we haue appertaineth to him, as our infirmities, and sinnes, and what hee hath doth belong to vs, as his Righteousnesse, and glorie.

Now, if the Deuill should call vs to answere for our debts, we may from these premises safely reply, that the wife is no sueable person, so long as her husband liueth; but our husband Iesus Christ is aliue, and liueth for euermore, let him therefore sue him if hee will, if he dare, and he will answere him to the extent of Law; but as for vs, wee are vnder the couer-barne of his protection.
Or else, we may answere thus.

That is wee our selues, were lyable to pay our owne debts (as in true construction in our selues we are) yet, if we in beholding of our own insufficiencie, & being therby inforced to pleade for mercie, if heerein vpon our piteous & humble moane, some louing friend, taking compassion on vs, should vndertake the answere, and either compound, or discharge our debt, we then assuredly know, that a debt once discharged, is neuer more to be demanded, and so we gratiously stand freed, in the great and fearefull day of accompt. And such a mercifull and louing friend wee haue, euen Iesus Christ the righteous, who by joyning of two natures in one; God and man: As man, he hath sustained the punishment due for sinne; and as God, hath conquered and
ouercome for vs, giuing vs discharge and release thereby.

row.cell: Oh the depth of Gods wisedome in

div.p: Mercy, in forgiuing of sinne.
Iudgement, in the punishment of sinne.
Mercy, in pardoning the elect in his Sonne.
Iudgement, in scourging sinne with a curse.
Mercy, in that punishing our sinnes, yet he doth it not in our selues (who were not able to beare it) but in his Sonne, who is both willing and able to sustaine it.

Or to conclude, we may further answere thus: Faith is the hand & instrument whereby we are assured, of the remission of sinne and consequently of eternall Saluation: and that the Lord will race our sinnes out of the booke of accompt, so that they shall be forgotten, and forgiuen, neuer more to be remembred, to be imputed, ne nominari quidem, not so much as to be once mentioned, and therefore they are called peccata tecta, sinnes hidden, sinnes couered, Psa. 32. 1.
And this faith assureth vs, that he is
The good samaritane, who hath wine and oyle for our deadly wounds.
The carefull sHeepheard, that diligently seeketh vp the lost sheepe.
The pitifull creditor, who forgaue vs ten thousand tallents.
The louing Father, who at all times is readie to receiue the Prodigall sonne.
The true Serpen • , a present helpe for all those that looke vpon him by faith, being stung to death by sinne.

p.hi: The Lambe of God, that taketh away the sinnes of the World, Ioh. 1.

div.p: So that the close of the whole point of remission of sinnes, is this; We must know, that there is no satisfaction, praeter meritum Christi, and therefore, whatsoeuer we doe, in way to obtaine remission of sinnes; we must doe it, as Mary heere, and as all the godly else do, per modum obedientiae, non per modum satisfactionis, as we haue said.
Let me I pray you, adde heereunto one extrauagant Obseruance more, so I will make an end, viz.

When the commandement came, sinne reuiued, when the spirit of God once re • ealeth to vs the true sence and meaning of the Law; and hath taught vs to compare our actions therewith; then sinne rouzeth it selfe and reuiueth, yea that sinne that lay hid before in securitie, and as it were couched in his furrow, doth now appeare. This reuiuing of sin,
vringeth a shame with it, the shame of si • bringeth sorrow for it, and the sorrow for i • doth afford amendment of life with it. An • yet though this practise be neuer so profitable, be neuer so comfortable, yet we finde i • true by woful experience, that we can least o • al endure to see our sinne, to know it, or to b • reproued for it. To be sorrie for our sins, is a • enterance to repentance, to raise vp our selue • by faith to remission is the consummation.

By sorrow to acknowledge thy sinne, to accuse thy selfe, to detest the one, and to condemne the other, is an ingredient: by Faith to aspire, and to attaine to grace, is the confection. But when Christ is laid hold on by faith in Repentance, whereby sinnes are released and the Holy-Ghost giuen, that is the perfection.

And in whomsoeuer the Holyghost doth thus gratiously reside, the outward workes which flow from such a Repentance (as his liuely and gratious effects) doe seale it before men, testifie it in our selues, and approue it before God, that we are his Children. For which rich mercy, and vnutterable grace, we ascribe as duly doth belong to this ternall, eternall maiestie, all honor and glorie, now and for euermore.
